results.title: Medicina Amara (Turkish)
results.creator_credit: Jessica Douglas-Henry, Sabina Wynn and Leichardt Women's Community Health Centre
results.brief_description: Medicina amara explores the personal experiences of migrant women in Australia and their use of tranquillisers. Through a dramatised reconstruction the video explores reasons that compel women to seek help and the common medical response. This video suggests alternatives to medication and presents women’s personal experiences and their determination to face life pill-free.

results.title: Medical Breakthroughs and Prevention
results.brief_description: Worldwide, millions of dollars have been spent on researching ways to combat one of the most deadly and feared diseases known to mankind - cancer. The “Beyond 2000” team takes a penetrating global look at the very latest methods being used to treat cancer and assist existing sufferers. In addition, they examine how preventative medicine is playing an increasingly important role in the war to stop cancer.

results.title: Mediaeval village
results.creator_credit: J.B. Holmes, H.L. Beales, R.S. Lambert and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The social history of Laxton, a village in England in which the medieval open-field system is still used, is traced from monuments and documents. The first map of Laxton, made in 1630, shows the village and the church, and the three open fields divided into strips. Village life as it exists today, with its small individual farmsteads and strip cultivation with crop rotation, is shown to be almost identical with the system displayed on the 1630 map. The second half of the film shows the survival from feudal times of the Manorial Court, or Court Leet. The jury makes the round of the wheat-bearing field, replaces boundary pegs, and imposes fines for encroachment. The Pinder rounds up stray cattle and drives them into the pound. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Mediaeval England
results.creator_credit: W. Hugh Baddeley, Clement W. Bending and Gateway Film Productions
results.brief_description: Gives a general account of life in medieval England, looking at the life and work of the peasants, the three field system of agriculture, houses of the rich and poor, the church and monastry, the work of the monks and nuns and Holy Day celebrations. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Mediaeval castles
results.brief_description: The Normans built the first castles in England which were simply raised earthworks, with a wooden palisading, surrounded by a ditch. Stone eventually replaced wood. The keep was the central point and its layout and function is explained. Illustrates the methods by which castles were attacked and design improvements of the 12th and 13th Centuries. By the end of the 13th Century castles were built with double walls and nearly impregnable, but the need for them was lessening. The greater part of this program consists of animated drawings and diagrams.

results.title: Media project: a film about media coverage of the Gulf War and memory
results.creator_credit: Peter Watkins, Chris Haywood and Watkins Rapier productions
results.brief_description: Raises debate on the global media coverage of the Gulf War by taking examples from the Australian media coverage of the event and having them discussed by a small group of people from different backgrounds who are having dinner together. Written by Peter Watkins in conjunction with the cast, many of whom are expressing their own feelings and concerns. A Teaching guide accompanies the video and is available for separate loan.

results.title: Media matters: an easy guide to getting media coverage
results.brief_description: Media Matters gives you the who, when, where and how of getting the media interested in your story and then tells you how to follow through. It also tells you how the media works. The kit comprises a video and comprehensive written guide covering ideas on how to package a story and make it interesting to the media and the audience. It is designed for individuals and voluntary groups involved in promoting fitness and healthy lifestyles in the community and can be used to publicise activities and attract membership. The video contains case studies of groups that have succeeded in getting coverage and interviews with working journalists.

results.title: Media law
results.creator_credit: Bennet Berkov, Annenberg and CPB Project
results.brief_description: Focuses on reporters’ rights and defemses for potential libel or invasion of privacy lawsuits as well as concepts like open meeting, shield and freedom of information laws. Discusses legal issues that may confront students working for a school newspaper or other publication.
